Award.AwardTitle: Manufacturing Associate Degree Education in Northwestern Connecticut

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As advanced manufacturing moves forward in the Nation, there is an increasing need to prepare a skilled, flexible, and innovative workforce. This project is developing an advanced manufacturing technician associate degree program that is designed to increase the number of skilled workers in the northwest corner of Connecticut (CT) and provide a pathway where students can pursue associate and bachelor degrees in manufacturing so they can advance their careers. The college is partnering with three school systems, the Northwest Connecticut Manufacturers Coalition (NCMC), and Regional Center for Next Generation Manufacturing (RCNGM). In addition, the college is a long-standing member of the Connecticut College of Technology (COT). As such, the college and its partners benefit from the best practices, curriculum, and articulations developed by the COT.

The project is increasing the partnerships between higher education and industry by creating a manufacturing technology program and a career pathway that can be adopted by other high schools and community colleges especially those in rural areas, and by increasing the number of high school and community college students interested in pursuing careers in manufacturing.

Surveys of the manufacturers in the northwest region helped to identify four industry-driven, workforce-based needs that are being addressed in this project:
1. Recruitment: Recruiting a skilled manufacturing workforce requires raising awareness of career possibilities within advanced technology and manufacturing fields. This project is continuing with current outreach programs to junior high and high school students to inform future skilled workers. It is also exposing unemployed, underemployed, displaced, and incumbent workers to the necessary skill sets and career possibilities of manufacturing within northwestern CT.
2. Education: A majority of manufacturers in advanced technological sectors nationwide indicate that they have a difficult time filling positions because applicants lack the necessary skills for the job. This project is developing a degree pathway that provides workers with advanced technology skills to meet workforce needs.
3. Retention: Manufacturing employers in northwestern CT have difficulty retaining employees who live outside of the area. Many employees who have the appropriate skills do not want to travel or move to rural CT and therefore end up leaving after they are trained. This project is focusing on providing people who already live in the northwest corner of the state with the skills and education they need to obtain jobs in the advanced manufacturing sector.
4. Continued education and career advancement: Modern manufacturing requires workers to keep up with technology. Incumbent workers also need skills for advancement. Both of these require a strong partnership between manufacturers and the college. This project strengthens that collaboration and provides workers with a pathway to advance their education.

Investigator.EmailAddress: A L E X A G R E G @ S B C G L O B A L . N E T

POR.DRECONTENT:
Northwestern Connecticut Community College is a small community college in rural Connecticut with a strong focus on liberal arts programs. In 2014, Northwestern Connecticut Community College was awarded a New to ATE Grant to develop a manufacturing associate degree program and to build stronger ties with manufacturers in the region. The intellectual merit of our project was met by developing a Technology Studies: Manufacturing Technology Associates Degree Program.  The program was developed with input from the Northwest Connecticut Chamber of Commerce's Manufacturing Coalition in order that students will be workforce ready.  As part of this new program, we developed 10 new courses in manufacturing including courses in Blueprint Reading, Manufacturing Processes, CNC I and II, Precision Machining, MasterCam, and SolidWorks. Students can earn up to 11 credentials through the National Institute of Metalworking Skills (NIMS) in their courses. On average 92% of the students attempting NIMS credentials received them.

We also developed three stackable certificate programs that allow students to gain new knowledge and skills in the area of advanced manufacturing. All of the courses in the certificates can be applied to the associate degree. The associate degree transfers into the Industrial Technology bachelor's degree program at Central Connecticut State University.

The broader impacts of our project were addressed by increasing the partnerships between higher education and industry.  A survey of 17 local manufacturing employers indicated strong support for the training and education Northwestern's program offers, with approximately 90% stating that the formal courses and/or an associate degree program are very  valuable to extremely valuable in preparing workers for manufacturing technology careers. Three quarters of those surveyed reported that they had sent current employees to Northwestern to gain specific job skills. Our students are current employed by 12 local companies.

The program has also resulted in an increase in the number of high school and community college students interested in pursuing careers in manufacturing. Over the course of our project, 134 students enrolled in our manufacturing courses. Of those, 55% were high school students enrolled through our High School Partnership (HSP) program. The majority of our HSP students came from comprehensive high schools.  In addition, we developed four dual enrollment (DE) courses with the local technical school, Oliver Wolcott Technical High School. Students taking these DE courses at the high school earn college credit. The success rate of students enrolled in our manufacturing courses is 88%.

Modified by: Sharon Gusky

In 2014, Northwestern Connecticut Community College was awarded a New to ATE Grant to develop a manufacturing associate degree program and to build stronger ties with manufacturers in the region. The intellectual merit of our project was met by developing a Technology Studies: Manufacturing Technology Associates Degree Program. We also developed three stackable certificate programs that allow students to gain new knowledge and skills in the area of advanced manufacturing. All of the courses in the certificates can be applied to the associate degree. The broader impacts of our project were addressed by increasing the partnerships between higher education and industry. A survey of 17 local manufacturing employers indicated strong support for the training and education Northwestern's program offers, with approximately 90% stating that the formal courses and/or an associate degree program are very valuable to extremely valuable in preparing workers for manufacturing technology careers. Three quarters of those surveyed reported that they had sent current employees to Northwestern to gain specific job skills. Our students are current employed by 12 local companies. The program has also resulted in an increase in the number of high school and community college students interested in pursuing careers in manufacturing. Over the course of our project, 134 students enrolled in our manufacturing courses. Of those, 55% were high school students enrolled through our High School Partnership (HSP) program. The majority of our HSP students came from comprehensive high schools. In addition, we developed four dual enrollment (DE) courses with the local technical school, Oliver Wolcott Technical High School. Students taking these DE courses at the high school earn college credit. The success rate of students enrolled in our manufacturing courses is 88%.
